definition: the Japanese Meiji Restoration of 1868
Ming Dynasty (1368-1644)/surname Ming/Ming (c. 2000 BC), fourth of the legendary Flame Emperors, 炎帝[Yan2 di4] descended from Shennong 神農|神农[Shen2 nong2] Farmer God
bright/opposite: dark 暗[an4]/(of meaning) clear/to understand/next/public or open/wise/generic term for a sacrifice to the gods

abbr. for Uighur 維吾爾|维吾尔[Wei2 wu2 er3]/surname Wei
to preserve/to maintain/to hold together/dimension/vitamin (abbr. for 維生素|维生素[wei2 sheng1 su4])

new/newly/meso- (chemistry)

sentences.english: Japan accelerated its invasion and external expansion after the Meiji Restoration.
sentences.chinese: 日本在明治维新以后加快对外侵略扩张。

sentences.english: Seemingly, success in Japan should be attributed to Meiji Reform or Restoration implemented in 1868.
sentences.chinese: 表面上看，日本的成功归因于1868年的明治维新。

sentences.english: After the Meiji Restoration, Japan quickly went on the path of capitalist development.
sentences.chinese: 日本明治维新后，迅速走上资本主义的发展道路。

definition: First Sino-Japanese War (1894-95)
to abandon the old (Asian) ways and learn from Europe/refers to the ideas that led to the Meiji Restoration and Japan's subsequent colonization projects in Asia
Kamakura bakufu 1192-1333, the first Japanese samurai shogunate
the war of 1904-1905 between Russia and Japan
Nara period (710-794) in early Japanese history
to abolish the feudal Han and introduce modern prefectures (refers to reorganization during Meiji Japan)
Edo (old name of Tokyo)
Fukuzawa Yukichi (1835-1901), prominent Japanese Westernizer, liberal educator and founder of Keio University
Muromachi bakufu, the feudal government of Japan (1338-1573) under the Ashikaga shoguns
militarism
Asuka Period in Japanese history (538-710 AD)
TOYOTOMI Hideyoshi (1536-1598), Japanese warlord, undisputed ruler of Japan 1590-1598
Oukubo Toshimichi (1830-1878), Japanese politician
the Opium Wars of 1840-1842 and 1860-1861
bourgeois revolution (in Marx-Leninist theory, a prelude to the proletarian revolution)
